title: China’s Economic Downturn Gives Rise to a Winter of Discontent
sub_head: With Xi likely seeking a third term, his critics may have more leverage than they have had for years.
body:
China’s economic future isn’t looking all that bright and is starting to have political implications for President Xi Jinping. The Chinese Academy of Social Sciences expects annual growth to slow to 5.3% in 2022 from 8% in 2021. Real-estate giant Evergrande, declared in default last month by ratings agencies, unleashed a wave of defaults in the country’s property sector, which is worth about 29% of gross domestic product.
Evergrande , with $300 billion in liabilities, is only the tip of the iceberg—one of many problems flowing from economic-policy decisions made in Beijing. Political reverberations of those decisions are emerging in China’s official media.
